questions.question: A student tests how the mass of a ball affects the distance it travels when hit by a bat. In this experiment, what is the 'mass of the ball' considered to be?
questions.explanation: The independent variable is the factor that is deliberately changed or manipulated by the experimenter to observe its effect on the dependent variable (distance traveled).

questions.question: A researcher writes: 'If the concentration of salt in water increases, then the boiling point will rise.' Name this specific step of the scientific method.
questions.explanation: A hypothesis is a testable prediction stated in an 'If...then...' format about the relationship between variables.

questions.question: The mass of a specific protein molecule is approximately $0.000000000000000000084\text{ kg}$. Express this mass in scientific notation.
questions.explanation: Move the decimal point 20 places to the right: $0.000000000000000000084 = 8.4 \times 10^{-20}\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A star's core temperature is $15{,}700{,}000\text{ K}$. Express this temperature in scientific notation.
questions.explanation: Move the decimal point 7 places to the left: $15{,}700{,}000 = 1.57 \times 10^7\text{ K}$.

questions.question: How many significant figures are in the measurement $0.0030200\text{ s}$?
questions.explanation: Leading zeros are not significant. The digits $3$, $0$, $2$, $0$, and the trailing $0$ are significant, giving a total of 5 significant figures.

questions.question: Identify which of the following is a fundamental (base) quantity in physics.
questions.explanation: Luminous intensity is one of the seven SI base quantities. Electric charge, frequency, and force are derived quantities.

questions.question: Identify which of the following is a derived quantity.
questions.explanation: Density is derived from mass and volume ($\rho = m/V$). Time, length, and mass are fundamental quantities.

questions.question: Which of the following is a fundamental SI unit?
questions.explanation: The candela (cd) is the SI base unit for luminous intensity. Pascal, Coulomb, and Joule are derived units.

questions.question: Which of the following is a derived SI unit?
questions.explanation: The Tesla (T) is a derived unit for magnetic flux density. Meter, kilogram, and second are fundamental SI units.

questions.question: A racing drone flies at a speed of $198\text{ km/h}$. Convert this speed to meters per second ($\text{m/s}$).
questions.explanation: To convert from km/h to m/s, divide by $3.6$: $198 \div 3.6 = 55\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A professional baseball pitch is thrown at $42\text{ m/s}$. What is its speed in kilometers per hour ($\text{km/h}$)?
questions.explanation: To convert from m/s to km/h, multiply by $3.6$: $42 \times 3.6 = 151.2\text{ km/h}$.

questions.question: A micro-screw has a length of $0.0035\text{ m}$. How many millimeters (mm) is this length?
A guitar string is $650\text{ mm}$ long. Express this length in meters.
questions.explanation: $1\text{ mm} = 0.001\text{ m}$, so $650\text{ mm} = 650 \times 0.001 = 0.65\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A bookshelf is $145\text{ cm}$ tall. What is this height expressed in meters?
questions.explanation: $1\text{ m} = 100\text{ cm}$, so $145\text{ cm} = 145 \div 100 = 1.45\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A desktop surface has an area of $5{,}000\text{ cm}^2$. Convert this area to square meters ($\text{m}^2$).
A swimmer swims $50\text{ m}$ due North, then immediately turns around and swims $10\text{ m}$ due South. The entire trip takes $20\text{ s}$. Calculate the swimmer's average velocity.
questions.explanation: Displacement is $50\text{ m}$ North minus $10\text{ m}$ South, which equals $40\text{ m}$ North. Average velocity $= \text{displacement} / \text{time} = 40\text{ m} / 20\text{ s} = 2\text{ m/s}$ North.

questions.question: A motorcycle increases its speed uniformly from $4\text{ m/s}$ to $28\text{ m/s}$ in $8\text{ s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the motorcycle's acceleration.
questions.explanation: Acceleration is calculated using $a = \frac{v_f - v_i}{t} = \frac{28 - 4}{8} = \frac{24}{8} = 3\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A train moving at $45\text{ m/s}$ slows down uniformly to $15\text{ m/s}$ in $10\text{ s}$. Calculate the acceleration of the train, including the correct sign to indicate direction.
questions.explanation: $a = \frac{15 - 45}{10} = \frac{-30}{10} = -3\text{ m/s}^2$. The negative sign indicates that the acceleration is in the direction opposite to the velocity (deceleration).

questions.question: A dog runs $25\text{ m}$ away from its starting point and then $25\text{ m}$ back to the start. The entire trip takes $10\text{ s}$. Calculate the dog's average speed and the magnitude of its average velocity.
questions.explanation: Average speed is total distance over time: $\frac{50\text{ m}}{10\text{ s}} = 5\text{ m/s}$. Average velocity is displacement over time: displacement $= 0$ (returns to start), so velocity $= 0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A scout walks $8\text{ km}$ due East and then $15\text{ km}$ due North. Calculate the total distance traveled and the magnitude of the scout's displacement from the starting point.
questions.explanation: Total distance is the sum of the path lengths: $8 + 15 = 23\text{ km}$. Displacement is the straight-line distance from start to finish, found using the Pythagorean theorem: $\sqrt{8^2 + 15^2} = \sqrt{289} = 17\text{ km}$.

questions.question: An elevator moves upward $2\text{ m}$ every second consistently. What type of motion does this describe?
questions.explanation: Equal distances covered in equal time intervals indicates uniform motion with a constant speed of $2\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: On a displacement-time graph, the line is straight and sloping downward toward the time axis (x-axis). Describe the velocity of the object.
questions.explanation: A straight line with a constant negative slope on a displacement-time graph indicates uniform negative velocity (the object is moving backward at a constant speed).

questions.question: A velocity-time graph shows a horizontal line at $35\text{ m/s}$. What is the acceleration of the object?
questions.explanation: A horizontal line on a velocity-time graph means the velocity is constant (not changing). Therefore, the acceleration is zero.

questions.question: A hockey puck slides across an ice rink. If no friction or air resistance acts on it, describe its motion according to Newton's First Law.
options: It will slow down and eventually stop
It will continue moving at a constant velocity in a straight line
It will move in a circular path
questions.explanation: Newton's First Law of Motion states that an object in motion will stay in motion with the same speed and in the same direction (constant velocity) unless acted upon by a net external force.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the net force required to accelerate a $4.5\text{ kg}$ mass at $8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Applying Newton's Second Law: $F = ma = 4.5\text{ kg} \times 8\text{ m/s}^2 = 36\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A person rows a boat by pushing the water backward with a force of $150\text{ N}$. According to Newton's Third Law, what force does the water exert on the oars?
questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Therefore, the water exerts a force of $150\text{ N}$ forward on the oars.

questions.question: Calculate the weight of a $2.5\text{ kg}$ laptop on Earth, where the acceleration due to gravity $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Weight is given by $W = mg = 2.5\text{ kg} \times 9.8\text{ m/s}^2 = 24.5\text{ N}$.

questions.question: An object weighs $140\text{ N}$ on a planet where the acceleration due to gravity is $7\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the mass of the object?
questions.explanation: From $W = mg$, the mass is $m = \frac{W}{g} = \frac{140\text{ N}}{7\text{ m/s}^2} = 20\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A $15\text{ kg}$ crate is resting on a horizontal floor. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the crate and the floor is $0.4$. Calculate the force of friction acting on the crate if it is sliding. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$).
questions.explanation: The friction force is $f = \mu N = \mu mg = 0.4 \times 15 \times 10 = 60\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A sliding object experiences a kinetic friction force of $48\text{ N}$. The coefficient of kinetic friction is $0.6$. Find the mass of the object. ($g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Using $f = \mu mg$, we solve for mass: $m = \frac{f}{\mu g} = \frac{48}{0.6 \times 10} = 8\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A $2\text{ kg}$ box is placed on top of an $8\text{ kg}$ flatbed cart. A horizontal force of $50\text{ N}$ is applied to the cart. Assuming no friction, calculate the acceleration of the cart and box together.
questions.explanation: The total mass being accelerated is $2\text{ kg} + 8\text{ kg} = 10\text{ kg}$. Using Newton's Second Law, $a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{50\text{ N}}{10\text{ kg}} = 5\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $5\text{ kg}$ cart and a $15\text{ kg}$ cart are tied together by a rope and pulled by an $80\text{ N}$ force across a frictionless surface. What is the acceleration of the system?
questions.explanation: The total mass is $5 + 15 = 20\text{ kg}$. The acceleration is $a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{80\text{ N}}{20\text{ kg}} = 4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A heavy desk is pushed across a floor at a constant velocity with a force of $95\text{ N}$. What is the magnitude of the frictional force acting on the desk?
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means the net force is zero. Therefore, the applied force must exactly balance the friction force: $f_{\text{friction}} = F_{\text{app}} = 95\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $120\text{ N}$ force pulls a $20\text{ kg}$ sled across a surface. The force of friction opposing the motion is $40\text{ N}$. What is the acceleration of the sled?
questions.explanation: The net force is $F_{\text{net}} = 120\text{ N} - 40\text{ N} = 80\text{ N}$. Acceleration is $a = \frac{F_{\text{net}}}{m} = \frac{80\text{ N}}{20\text{ kg}} = 4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $100\text{ N}$ horizontal force pushes a $10\text{ kg}$ block, causing it to accelerate at $7\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the magnitude of the frictional force acting on the block?
questions.explanation: The net force required to produce the acceleration is $F_{\text{net}} = ma = 10 \times 7 = 70\text{ N}$. Since the applied force is $100\text{ N}$, the friction force must be $F_{\text{friction}} = F_{\text{app}} - F_{\text{net}} = 100 - 70 = 30\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A swimmer moves through the water at a constant speed, overcoming $30\text{ N}$ of internal friction from their body and $50\text{ N}$ of water drag. What is the applied force provided by the swimmer?
questions.explanation: Constant velocity implies zero net force. Therefore, the swimmer's applied force must balance the total resistance: $F_{\text{app}} = 30\text{ N} + 50\text{ N} = 80\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A small plane's engine provides a thrust of $2{,}500\text{ N}$. The plane experiences a friction force of $600\text{ N}$. If the plane moves at a constant velocity, what is the magnitude of the air drag?
questions.explanation: At constant velocity, the net force is zero. Therefore, the thrust must equal the sum of the resistive forces: $2{,}500 = 600 + F_{\text{drag}}$, so $F_{\text{drag}} = 2{,}500 - 600 = 1{,}900\text{ N}$.

questions.question: The applied force on an object is $400\text{ N}$, and the air drag acting on it is $285\text{ N}$. If the object moves at a constant velocity, what is the magnitude of the mechanical friction?
questions.explanation: For constant velocity, the net force is zero, so the sum of resistive forces must equal the applied force. Therefore, $400 = 285 + f_{\text{friction}}$, so $f_{\text{friction}} = 400 - 285 = 115\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A person holds a dumbbell and slowly lowers it from their shoulder down to their waist at a constant speed. Is the work done by the person on the dumbbell positive, negative, or zero?
questions.explanation: The person exerts an upward force on the dumbbell to control its descent, while the displacement of the dumbbell is downward. Since the force and displacement are in opposite directions, the work done by the person is negative.

questions.question: A tugboat pulls a barge forward, moving the barge in the same direction as the force applied by the tugboat. Is the work done by the tugboat on the barge positive, negative, or zero?
questions.explanation: The tugboat exerts a forward force on the barge, and the barge's displacement is also forward. Force and displacement are in the same direction, so the work done by the tugboat is positive.

questions.question: A $4\text{ kg}$ bowling ball is sitting on a shelf that is $2\text{ m}$ above the floor. Calculate the ball's gravitational potential energy relative to the floor. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$).
questions.explanation: Gravitational potential energy is given by $GPE = mgh = 4\text{ kg} \times 10\text{ m/s}^2 \times 2\text{ m} = 80\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $0.1\text{ kg}$ arrow is shot and flies through the air at a speed of $40\text{ m/s}$. What is its kinetic energy?
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is calculated using $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}(0.1)(40)^2 = 0.05 \times 1{,}600 = 80\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A ball at the top of a hill has $100\text{ J}$ of gravitational potential energy. After rolling down the hill, it has $82\text{ J}$ of kinetic energy. How much energy was converted to heat due to friction?
questions.explanation: The energy lost to heat is the difference between the initial potential energy and the final kinetic energy: $100\text{ J} - 82\text{ J} = 18\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A rocket is launching from Earth, gaining both altitude and speed. Describe the changes in its kinetic energy (KE) and gravitational potential energy (PE).
options: Both KE and PE stay constant
questions.explanation: As the rocket gains speed, its KE increases. As it gains altitude, its PE increases. Therefore, both KE and PE are increasing.

questions.question: A skydiver is falling toward the ground and gaining speed. Ignoring air resistance, describe the energy transition that is occurring.
options: Both KE and PE are increasing
PE is decreasing while KE is increasing
PE is increasing while KE is decreasing
Both KE and PE are constant
questions.explanation: As the skydiver falls, height decreases (so PE decreases) and speed increases (so KE increases). Total mechanical energy is conserved in the absence of air resistance.

questions.question: A car drives at a constant speed of $60\text{ km/h}$ on a flat, horizontal road. What is the state of its gravitational potential energy (PE)?
questions.explanation: Constant altitude on a flat road means the height is constant, so the gravitational potential energy is constant.

questions.question: An unstretched spring has a length of $15\text{ cm}$. When a mass is hung from it, the spring stretches by $3.6\text{ cm}$. What is the new total length of the spring?
questions.explanation: The new length is the original length plus the extension: $15\text{ cm} + 3.6\text{ cm} = 18.6\text{ cm}$.

questions.question: A hoist uses $1{,}200\text{ J}$ of electrical energy to perform $900\text{ J}$ of useful work in lifting a load. Calculate the efficiency of the hoist.
questions.explanation: Efficiency is the ratio of useful work output to energy input, expressed as a percentage: $\left(\frac{900}{1{,}200}\right) \times 100\% = 75\%$.

questions.question: Calculate the total resistance of three resistors with resistances $15\,\Omega$, $35\,\Omega$, and $50\,\Omega$ when they are connected in series.
questions.explanation: For resistors in series, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistances: $R_{\text{total}} = 15 + 35 + 50 = 100\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the total equivalent resistance of three identical $120\,\Omega$ resistors when they are connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: For $n$ identical resistors in parallel, the equivalent resistance is $R_{\text{eq}} = \frac{R}{n} = \frac{120\,\Omega}{3} = 40\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two $10\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in series. This combination is then connected in parallel with a single $20\,\Omega$ resistor. Find the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The series pair has a resistance of $10 + 10 = 20\,\Omega$. This $20\,\Omega$ resistor is in parallel with the other $20\,\Omega$ resistor. The equivalent resistance is given by $\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{20} + \frac{1}{20} = \frac{2}{20} = \frac{1}{10} \rightarrow R = 10\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two $16\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in parallel. This combination is then connected in series with an $8\,\Omega$ resistor. Find the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel pair has an equivalent resistance of $\frac{16}{2} = 8\,\Omega$. Adding this in series with the $8\,\Omega$ resistor gives a total of $8 + 8 = 16\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the electrostatic force between two point charges of $8\,\mu\text{C}$ and $2\,\mu\text{C}$ separated by a distance of $0.04\text{ m}$ in a vacuum. (Use $k = 9 \times 10^9\text{ NÂ·m}^2/\text{C}^2$).
If the distance between two point charges is doubled ($2r$) and the magnitude of one charge is quadrupled ($4Q$), while the other charge remains the same, how does the original force $F$ change?
options: It becomes $1/4$ of the original force ($F/4$)
questions.explanation: Coulomb's Law states $F \propto \frac{q}{r^2}$. Quadrupling one charge multiplies the force by $4$. Doubling the distance divides the force by $4$. The net factor is $\frac{4}{4} = 1$, so the force remains unchanged.

questions.question: Three point charges, A ($+Q$), B ($-Q$), and C ($+Q$), are placed in a straight line with equal spacing between them. Charge A is on the left, B is in the middle, and C is on the right. What is the direction of the net electrostatic force on charge B?
options: Toward the left (A attracts B to the left)
Toward the right (C attracts B to the right)
Zero (the attractive forces from A and C are equal and opposite)
questions.explanation: Charge A ($+Q$) attracts charge B ($-Q$) to the left. Charge C ($+Q$) attracts charge B ($-Q$) to the right. Since the charges and distances are equal, these attractive forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction, resulting in a net force of zero on charge B.

questions.question: A $40\,\Omega$ lightbulb is connected to a $120\text{ V}$ household outlet. What current does it draw?
questions.explanation: Ohm's Law gives the current as $I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{120\text{ V}}{40\,\Omega} = 3\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A $10\,\Omega$ resistor has a current of $4\text{ A}$ flowing through it. What is the power dissipated by the resistor?
questions.explanation: Electrical power can be calculated using $P = I^2R = (4\text{ A})^2 \times 10\,\Omega = 16 \times 10 = 160\text{ W}$.

questions.question: A $25\,\Omega$ resistor is connected to a $100\text{ V}$ power supply. Find the power dissipated by the resistor.
questions.explanation: Using the formula $P = \frac{V^2}{R}$, we get $P = \frac{(100\text{ V})^2}{25\,\Omega} = \frac{10{,}000}{25} = 400\text{ W}$.

questions.question: If a charge of $480\text{ C}$ flows through a conductor in a time of $4$ minutes, what is the current in the conductor?
questions.explanation: First convert time to seconds: $4$ minutes $= 240\text{ s}$. Electric current is $I = \frac{Q}{t} = \frac{480\text{ C}}{240\text{ s}} = 2\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A very thin wire has a diameter of $0.6\text{ mm}$. Express this diameter in meters.
